awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides funding for the 2024 Spring and Fall Redbud Geometry/Topology Conferences, the first of which is to be held April 12-14, 2024, at Oklahoma State University. These conferences are part of an ongoing series of conferences held at universities in Arkansas and Oklahoma, intended to increase interaction and collaboration among early career and established mathematicians in the area. The Spring meeting will feature talks by prominent speakers from across North America, as well as a graduate student workshop. The Fall meeting will take place at the University of Oklahoma, and it will predominantly consist of talks by early-career mathematicians from the EPSCoR regions of Arkansas, Oklahoma, and surrounding states.

Many interesting results have linked low-dimensional topology and group orderability. These results have provided evidence for a prominent conjecture addressing which three-manifold groups are left-orderable, and have made progress towards a classification of bi-orderable three-manifold groups. The 2024 Spring Redbud Geometry/Topology Conference will bring together leading researchers to discuss these developments. The invited speakers are: Idrissa Ba (University of Manitoba), Adam Clay (University of Manitoba), Nathan Dunfield (University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign), Cameron Gordon (University of Texas at Austin), Ying Hu (University of Nebraska, Omaha), Tao Li (Boston College), Rachel Roberts (Washington University in St. Louis), Dale Rolfsen (University of British Columbia), and Hannah Turner (Georgia Institute of Technology). The conference begins with a workshop designed to enhance the experience of graduate students and junior researchers. The workshop will feature expository talks by Clay, Gordon, and Rolfsen. More information is available at the conference website: https://math.okstate.edu/conferences/redbud/

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This grant funded two conferences: a larger conference in Spring 2024 which brought together experts in low dimensional topology from around the US and Canada, and a smaller regional conference in Fall 2024. The Spring conference featured an introductory session aimed at graduate students, a department colloquium, five lightning talks by graduate student speakers, and eight main conference talks. The Fall conference featured six speakers from local universities.

Intellectual Merit: The main Spring conference focussed on relations between properties of three-dimensional spaces and various notions of orderability of groups associated to them. The L-space conjecture is a guiding goal in this area, positing an equivalence between three seemingly very different properties a space can have. Many of our speakers contributed key results in support of this conjecture and related issues. They were able to share their expertise in the field with other participants, describing both the techniques used to prove their results as well as open problems and future directions.

Broader impacts: The project provided opportunities for early career mathematicians to present their work, learn from experts in the field, and establish a research network to carry through their careers. The Spring conference featured talks by five graduate students and three postdoctoral fellows. Four of the speakers were women. The conference attendance consisted of 27 faculty members (21 male, 6 female), 8 postdoctoral fellows (6 male, 2 female), and 25 graduate students (17 male, 6 female).  The Fall conference featured talks by two graduate students, a postdoctoral fellow, and three assistant professors. One of the speakers was a woman. 

Outcomes: The two conferences are part of a shared commitment from the topology groups of the University of Oklahoma, Oklahoma State University and the University of Arkansas to hold regular meetings encouraging the interaction between students at our institutions and institutions in the region to participate in high level research activities. Overall researchers from 24 different institutions participated in the conferences. The demographics of the conference have traditionally skewed more towards early career scholars, which we were excited to see continue with this iteration of the conference. The three research groups at these schools share knowledge about what works and what can be improved with each implementation of the conference, which should set up future organizers for success even if it is their first time organizing a conference of this scope. 

 


Last Modified: 04/14/2025
Modified by: Henry Segerman
